section.title: Install the Database service
section.para: This procedure installs the Database module on the controller node.

formalpara.title: Prerequisites
formalpara.para: This chapter assumes that you already have a working OpenStack environment with at least the following components installed: Compute, Image Service, Identity.

listitem.para: If you want to do backup and restore, you also need Object Storage.
If you want to provision datastores on block-storage volumes, you also need Block Storage.

section.para: To install the Database module on the controller:

step.para: Install required packages:

screen.userinput: apt-get install python-trove python-troveclient \ trove-common trove-api trove-taskmanager trove-conductor

step.para: Respond to the prompts for database management and [keystone_authtoken] settings, and API endpoint registration. The trove-manage db_sync command runs automatically.
Prepare OpenStack:
Source the admin-openrc.sh file.
Create a trove user that Compute uses to authenticate with the Identity service. Use the service tenant and give the user the admin role:
Replace TROVE_PASS with a suitable password.
All configuration files should be placed at /etc/trove directory. Edit the following configuration files, taking the below actions for each file:
You need to take upstream api-paste.ini and change content below in it:
step.programlisting: [composite:trove] auth_uri = http://controller:5000/v2.0 identity_uri = http://controller:35357 auth_host = controller admin_tenant_name = service admin_user = trove admin_password = TROVE_PASS

step.para: Edit the [DEFAULT] section of each file (except api-paste.ini) and set appropriate values for the OpenStack service URLs (can be handled by Keystone service catalog), logging and messaging configuration, and SQL connections:
step.programlisting: [DEFAULT] log_dir = /var/log/trove trove_auth_url = http://controller:5000/v2.0 nova_compute_url = http://controller:8774/v2 cinder_url = http://controller:8776/v1 swift_url = http://controller:8080/v1/AUTH_ sql_connection = mysql://trove:TROVE_DBPASS@controller/trove notifier_queue_hostname = controller

step.para: Configure the Database module to use the RabbitMQ message broker by setting the following options in the [DEFAULT] configuration group of each file:
step.programlisting: [DEFAULT] control_exchange = trove rabbit_host = controller rabbit_userid = guest rabbit_password = RABBIT_PASS rabbit_virtual_host= / rpc_backend = trove.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu

step.para: Edit the trove.conf file so it includes appropriate values for the default datastore and network label regex as shown below:
step.programlisting: [DEFAULT] # Config option for showing the IP address that nova doles out add_addresses = True network_label_regex = ^NETWORK_LABEL$ control_exchange = trove

step.para: Edit the trove-taskmanager.conf file so it includes the required settings to connect to the OpenStack Compute service as shown below:
step.programlisting: [DEFAULT] # Configuration options for talking to nova via the novaclient. # These options are for an admin user in your keystone config. # It proxy's the token received from the user to send to nova via this admin users creds, # basically acting like the client via that proxy token. nova_proxy_admin_user = admin nova_proxy_admin_pass = ADMIN_PASS nova_proxy_admin_tenant_name = service taskmanager_manager = trove.taskmanager.manager.Manager log_file=trove-taskmanager.log

step.para: Prepare the trove admin database:

screen.userinput: GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON trove.* TO trove@'localhost' \ IDENTIFIED BY 'TROVE_DBPASS';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON trove.* TO trove@'%' \ IDENTIFIED BY 'TROVE_DBPASS';

step.para: Prepare the Database service:
Initialize the database:

Create a datastore. You need to create a separate datastore for each type of database you want to use, for example, MySQL, MongoDB, Cassandra. This example shows you how to create a datastore for a MySQL database:
Create a trove image.
Create an image for the type of database you want to use, for example, MySQL, MongoDB, Cassandra.

This image must have the trove guest agent installed, and it must have the trove-guestagent.conf file configured to connect to your OpenStack environment. To correctly configure the trove-guestagent.conf file, follow these steps on the guest instance you are using to build your image:
Add the following lines to trove-guestagent.conf:
step.programlisting: rabbit_host = controller rabbit_password = RABBIT_PASS nova_proxy_admin_user = admin nova_proxy_admin_pass = ADMIN_PASS nova_proxy_admin_tenant_name = service trove_auth_url = http://controller:35357/v2.0 log_file = trove-guestagent.log

step.para: Update the datastore and version to use the specific image with the trove-manage command.

screen.userinput: trove-manage datastore_version_update datastore_name version_name \ datastore_manager glance_image_id packages active

step.para: This example shows you how to create a MySQL datastore with version 5.5:

screen.userinput: trove-manage datastore_version_update mysql 5.5 mysql glance_image_ID mysql-server-5.5 1 #trove-manage datastore_update mysql 5.5

You must register the Database module with the Identity service so that other OpenStack services can locate it. Register the service and specify the endpoint:

screen.userinput: keystone service-create --name trove --type database \ --description "OpenStack Database Service"

keystone endpoint-create \ --service-id $(keystone service-list | awk '/ trove / {print $2}') \ --publicurl http://controller:8779/v1.0/%\(tenant_id\)s \ --internalurl http://controller:8779/v1.0/%\(tenant_id\)s \ --adminurl http://controller:8779/v1.0/%\(tenant_id\)s \ --region regionOne
